section.title: Overview
section.para: Scaly's type system is designed for maximum portability across backends. The compiler itself has no built-in knowledge of primitive types. Instead, all types — including integers, floats, and booleans — are defined in backend-specific prelude files.

section.title: Intrinsic Types
section.programlisting: define i32 intrinsic define i64 intrinsic define f64 intrinsic
section.para: The compiler does not interpret these definitions — it simply records that these types exist and are intrinsic. The backend (Emitter) is responsible for mapping intrinsic types to the target platform's representation.
This design enables Scaly to target any backend:

listitem.para: LLVM: i32, i64, f32, f64
JavaScript: number, string, boolean
WebAssembly: i32, i64, f32, f64
JVM: int, long, float, double

section.title: Type Aliases
section.para: Type aliases provide human-friendly names for intrinsic or compound types:
section.programlisting: define bool i1 define char i32 ; Unicode scalar value define int i64 ; Platform word size define size_t u64
section.para: The alias and its target are interchangeable — bool and i1 refer to the same type.

section.title: Backend Preludes
section.para: Each backend provides a prelude file that defines the intrinsic types and their aliases for that target. The prelude is implicitly loaded before any user code.

example.title: LLVM Prelude (excerpt)
example.programlisting:
; Intrinsic types (LLVM native) define i1 intrinsic define i8 intrinsic define i16 intrinsic define i32 intrinsic define i64 intrinsic define f32 intrinsic define f64 intrinsic define ptr intrinsic
; Human-friendly aliases define bool i1 define char i32 define int i64 define size_t u64

example.title: JavaScript Prelude (excerpt)
example.programlisting:
; Intrinsic types (JavaScript native) define number intrinsic define string intrinsic define boolean intrinsic
; Aliases for compatibility define int number define float number define bool boolean

section.title: Literal Type Inference
section.para: Numeric and other literals do not have an inherent type. Their type is inferred from context:
If the type cannot be inferred, the compiler requires an explicit annotation:
section.programlisting: let x 42 ; ERROR: cannot infer type for integer literal let x: i32 42 ; OK: type explicitly annotated
section.para: Scaly does not support type suffixes on literals (such as 42i32). This keeps literals clean and encourages explicit type annotations where they matter.

section.title: References and Aliasing
section.para: Scaly does not have reference types. There is no ref[T] or equivalent. This follows the ParaSail philosophy: no pointers or aliasing at the language level.

Values flow through functions. When a function receives a parameter, it gets read-only access (implemented as a pointer under the hood, but not exposed in the type system). When a function returns, it returns a value.

section.title: Low-Level Pointers
section.para: For low-level implementation of data structures like Page, HashMap, or List, the type pointer[T] is available. This is an escape hatch for implementors, not for everyday code.

section.title: Nullable Values
section.para: For nullable values, use Option[T] — a proper sum type with Some(value) and None variants:
The compiler optimizes Option[T] to a simple nullable pointer — no space overhead for the tag.

section.title: Parameter Passing
section.para: All function parameters are borrowed — functions receive read-only access to their arguments. The caller retains ownership.

section.title: Implementation
section.para: The implementation of parameter passing depends on the execution context, but the semantics remain identical:

listitem.para: Same thread/stack: A pointer is passed. No copying occurs. The function reads through the pointer.
Different thread/GPU/remote: The entire data tree is copied to the target execution context. The function still has read-only access — same semantics, different mechanism.

section.para: This design means code doesn't change based on where it executes. A function that works locally works identically when distributed.

section.title: Mutation via Procedures
section.para: To modify data, use a procedure instead of a function. Procedures can declare parameters as mutable:
The distinction between functions (pure, read-only) and procedures (may mutate) is explicit in the code. Readers immediately know which calls might have side effects.

section.title: Constructors
section.para: Constructors create instances of types. Scaly provides both implicit and explicit constructors.

section.title: Implicit Constructors
section.para: If all members of a type are public, an implicit constructor is generated that takes all fields as parameters in declaration order:
section.programlisting:
define Point { x: i32, y: i32 }
let p Point(10, 20) ; implicit constructor

section.title: Explicit Constructors
section.para: Use init for explicit constructors when you need:

listitem.para: Private members (implicit constructor unavailable)
Default values for some fields
Different construction signatures

section.title: The this Prefix
section.para: The this. prefix is optional when unambiguous, but recommended for clarity:
When parameter names shadow field names, this. is required to disambiguate. Avoid set x: x — it's confusing even if technically resolvable.

section.title: Complete Initialization
section.para: All fields must be initialized by any constructor — implicit or explicit. The compiler enforces this. There are no implicit default values (no automatic 0, false, or null):

section.title: Constructor Return
section.para: init implicitly returns this, enabling direct binding:
section.programlisting: let p Point(10, 20) ; init returns the new Point

section.title: Constructed Value Lifetime
section.para: The lifetime of a constructed value is inferred from context:

listitem.para: In a block: Local lifetime (current block)
Last statement / return position: Call lifetime (return page)
Explicit annotation: As specified

section.title: Page-Parameterized Constructors (init#)
section.para: Some types are value types (can live on the stack) but need to allocate internal data on a page. The init# syntax supports this pattern:
At call sites, the lifetime modifier determines which page is passed:

listitem.para: String#("hello") — passes caller's page (rp)
String$("world") — passes local page
String^hashMap("key") — passes the named page

section.para: The init# pattern is distinct from regular heap allocation. The struct itself can live on the stack — only its internal data needs a page. This is ideal for types like String, Array, or other containers where the wrapper is small but the content may be large.
Note: init$, init^, and init! are reserved for future use and will produce an error.

section.title: Closures (Lambdas)
section.para: Closures are anonymous functions defined with backslash syntax:
section.programlisting: \x: x * 2 ; single parameter \x y: x + y ; multiple parameters \: 42 ; no parameters

section.title: Capturing Variables
section.para: Closures can capture variables from their enclosing scope. Captured variables are treated as implicit borrowed parameters — read-only access, same as explicit function parameters:

section.title: Closures Are Pure
section.para: Closures cannot mutate captured variables. They are pure like functions, not imperative like procedures:
section.programlisting: var count 0 let bad \: { set count: count + 1 } ; ERROR: cannot mutate capture

section.title: Closure Lifetime
section.para: Since captures are borrowed, a closure cannot outlive its captured variables. The compiler enforces this through lifetime checking:

section.title: Implementation
section.para: Each closure is an anonymous struct containing its captures, with a call method implementing the body. Closures are monomorphized like other generic types.

section.title: Error Handling
section.para: Scaly uses explicit error handling. There are no exceptions or stack unwinding — errors are values returned from functions or procedures.

section.title: The throws Clause
section.para: Functions or procedures that can fail declare their error type with throws:
Under the hood, this is equivalent to returning Result[AST, ParseError], but with dedicated syntax for clarity.

section.title: Single Error Type
section.para: A function can only throw one error type. To represent multiple error kinds, use a union:
This ensures a clear error signature and enables the try/when pattern for handling specific variants.

section.title: The try/when Pattern
section.para: Handle errors with try and when clauses:
If not all error variants are covered, an else clause is required:

section.title: Error Propagation
section.para: Use else throw to re-throw errors to the caller:
When the error type matches exactly, the error propagates automatically. This simplifies deeply nested code like parsers and visitors.

section.title: Error Lifetime
section.para: Thrown values must have thrown lifetime (!). The compiler infers this from throw position. If inference fails, annotate explicitly:
section.programlisting: throw ParseError.InvalidSyntax(pos, msg)! ; explicit thrown lifetime
section.para: The caller provides the exception region where the error will be stored.

section.title: Union Types
section.para: A union type (also called sum type or tagged union) can hold one of several variants. Each variant can have its own fields:

section.title: Memory Layout
section.para: A union is stored as a tag plus the largest variant:
section.programlisting: Shape = { tag: u8, data: [size of largest variant] }
section.para: Unions can contain other unions. Nested unions contribute their full size (tag + data) when computing the parent union's size.

section.title: Pattern Matching with choose
section.para: Use choose-when to match on variants:
section.programlisting: choose s when Circle(r): computeCircleArea(r) when Rectangle(w, h): w * h when Triangle(a, b, c): heronArea(a, b, c)
section.para: If not all variants are covered, an else clause is required:
section.programlisting: choose s when Circle(r): computeCircleArea(r) else 0.0 ; handles Rectangle and Triangle

section.title: Option Type
section.para: Option[T] is a union for nullable values:

section.title: Option Optimization
section.para: For non-pointer types, Option[T] optimizes to a pointer:

listitem.para: None = null pointer
Some(value) = pointer to value

section.para: Note that if T is itself a pointer, the Option Optimization leads to a pointer to another pointer which could be null itself.

section.title: Generics
section.para: Scaly supports generic types with type parameters in square brackets:

section.title: Monomorphization
section.para: Generics are implemented via monomorphization: each concrete instantiation becomes a completely separate type at compile time. List[i32] and List[String] share no code at runtime — each has its own specialized implementation.
Benefits:

listitem.para: No runtime overhead — no type descriptors or vtables
Full optimization — the compiler sees concrete types
No boxing — primitives stay primitives

section.para: Trade-offs:

listitem.para: Larger binaries — each instantiation duplicates code
Longer compile times — more code to generate

section.title: Name Mangling
section.para: The Planner generates unique mangled names for each instantiation, following Itanium ABI conventions:
section.programlisting: List[i32] → _ZN4ListIiE... List[String] → _ZN4ListI6StringE... HashMap[String, i32] → _ZN7HashMapI6StringiE...
section.para: These names are compatible with c++filt for debugging.

section.title: Lifetimes and Memory Regions
section.para: Scaly uses Region-Based Memory Management (RBMM). Instead of garbage collection or manual malloc/free, values are allocated in memory regions (pages) that are deallocated in bulk when their owning scope exits.

section.title: Stack vs Page Allocation
section.para: The presence or absence of a lifetime suffix on a constructor call determines whether the value is stack-allocated or page-allocated:

listitem.para: The value is allocated on the stack frame. Fast, automatic cleanup when the function returns. Cannot outlive the current function.
The value is allocated on a memory page. Can outlive the current block depending on which lifetime is used.

section.programlisting: let stack_point Point(10, 20) ; stack-allocated (by value) let page_point Point$(10, 20) ; page-allocated (local page)
section.para: Note: The lifetime suffix comes before the constructor parameters, not after. This follows the general pattern: Type + Generics + Lifetime + Parameters.

listitem.para: Value is allocated on a local page that lives until the end of the current block. The page is lazily allocated on first use and automatically deallocated when the block exits.
Value is allocated on the caller's return page. It survives the function return and is managed by the caller. Used for returning heap-allocated values.
Value is allocated on the exception page. Used for error values that may be thrown and caught by the caller.
Value is allocated on the same page as the named variable. The named variable must itself be page-allocated (not stack-allocated). Used when adding values to collections.

section.title: Local Lifetime ($)
section.para: Local lifetime allocates on a page scoped to the current block. The page is lazily allocated (only when needed) and automatically freed when the block exits:
Important: Local lifetime ($) is forbidden on return types. A function cannot return a value with local lifetime because the local page is deallocated before the caller receives the value.

section.title: Caller Lifetime (#)
section.para: Values that must survive a function return use caller lifetime. The value is allocated on the caller's page, not the function's local page:
The compiler may infer caller lifetime for values in return position when the return type specifies it.

section.title: Thrown Lifetime (!)
section.para: Error values use thrown lifetime. The value is allocated on a special exception page provided by the caller:
The compiler infers thrown lifetime for values in throw position.

section.title: Reference Lifetime (^name)
section.para: When adding a value to a collection, the value must be allocated on the same page as the collection. Use reference lifetime with the collection's name:
section.programlisting: let items Array$() ; items is page-allocated let item Car^items("red") ; item allocated on same page as items items.add(item) ; safe - same lifetime
section.para: Validation: The compiler verifies that the referenced variable (items in this example) is page-allocated. Referencing a stack-allocated variable is an error:
This prevents dangling references: you cannot tie a value's lifetime to a stack variable that will be destroyed when the function returns.

section.title: By-Value Returns
section.para: Functions can return values by value (no lifetime annotation). This is the simplest approach for small types:
By-value return avoids page allocation entirely. The value is constructed directly in the caller's stack frame or register.

section.title: Lifetime Inference
section.para: The compiler infers lifetimes where possible:

listitem.para: No suffix on constructor = stack allocation (by value)
Throw position implies thrown lifetime (!)
Reference lifetime (^container) must always be explicit
$, # must be explicit on constructor calls
